title: Your Presentation Title Here
section: Making your Slides FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable)
text:
Making your Slides FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable)
Step 1 create a new repository on your GitHub name this yourGitHubusername.github.io  Step 2 Add an readme file and type hello! This will be your home page. Any time you work on a new repository and publish this it will be a sub-directory of the page.  Step 3 Clone the repository from the following link https://omiridoue.github.io/20240814_PaNs  Step 4 There are many ways to host your the presentation you have rendered through Quarto. We will render this locally and deploy from our GitHub branch.

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Continued - Follow Along Today’s Material
Step 5 Create a repository on your GitHub name this 20240814_PaNs  Step 6 Follow the steps from https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/getting-started-with-git/managing-remote-repositories to sync your local and remote repositories, make sure to push all this content to your remote repository. The aim is to make your slides public and findable under the following URL https://yourGitHubusername.github.io/20240814_PaNs. Note if you have a GitHub Education page you don’t need to make the repository public, but your slides will be public.

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Continued - Follow Along Today’s Material

section: Quarto recognises ## as a command to make a new slide
text:
Quarto recognises ## as a command to make a new slide
Customise these headings by tinkering with the styles.css file. Maybe we can come up with a Quarto template for SPHSU branding? To tinker with the fonts/colors go to the styles.css document and navigate to the different heading definitions.
Heading 3 - three #’s
Heading 4 - four #’s
Heading 5 - five #’s
Heading 6 - six #’s

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Features in your Text
If you want to start a new line of text add a <br> at the end  of a line 
You can make text bold by adding two asterisks on either end of a phrase
Add Text to Your Hyperlink
Anything you wrap inside these back ticks will appear as highlighted text in line for example Ctrl+R.

title: Your Presentation Title Here
section: Code Chunk Explained a Bit More
text:
Code Chunk Explained a Bit More
The code chunks will include all your code, you can click Insert a new code chunk to your top right. Each chunk should have its own name. You can add a name after the first reserved word which refers to the language your code is in, this will be lowercase r for any R code. Follow the chunk name by a comma, for names try avoiding dashes, if there is an error with your code the error message will let you know which chunk has an issue. To evaluate, run the code, you will need to type eval = TRUE, if you do not want to run this code when you render the document change to FALSE. If you want to print your code in the slides add echo = TRUE.

library(network)

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Components
Alerts & Cross-refs
To emphasize specific words or text, you can:

Use the default .alert class, e.g. important note.
Use the .fg class for custom colour, e.g. important note.
Use the .bg class for custom background, e.g. important note.

To cross-reference, you have several options, for example:

Beamer-like .button class provided by this theme, e.g. Appendix
Quarto’s native cross-ref syntax, e.g., “See Section 1.17.”

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Components
Citations
Citations follow the standard Quarto format and be sourced from BibLaTex, BibTeX, or CLS files. For example:

Topic 1: Older Studies (Rogers 1983; Kermack and McKendrick 1939; Wasserman and Faust 1994)
Topic 2: Studies during 90’s (Valente 1996)

title: Your Presentation Title Here
section: Quarto allows you to have different tabs
text:
Quarto allows you to have different tabs

(a) Low prevalence(b) Moderate Prevalence(c) High Prevalence



low_prevalence <- rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.1)    # provide your own parameters
length(low_prevalence) 

[1] 100

head(low_prevalence)

[1] 1 1 3 2 0 0





moderate_prevalence <- rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.4)    # provide your own parameters
length(moderate_prevalence) 

[1] 100

head(moderate_prevalence)

[1] 2 2 3 4 3 2





high_prevalence <- rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.6)     # provide your own parameters
length(high_prevalence) 

[1] 100

head(high_prevalence)

[1] 7 6 4 6 5 7

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Results Section

library(psych)
library(knitr)

summary_samples <- rbind(low_smoking = describe(low_prevalence,quant=c(.25,.75) ), 
                         moderate_smoking = describe(moderate_prevalence,quant=c(.25,.75) ), 
                         high_smoking = describe(high_prevalence,quant=c(.25,.75)) )

summary_samples <- summary_samples[,c("mean","se", "sd", "min", "Q0.25", "median", "Q0.75", "max")]

kable(summary_samples)

You can wrap LaTeX code in line, to do this use a single dollar sign on either end of your code \(x\). You can also dynamically refer to a variable output in line, simply use back-ticks around your in line code in this case R. The rounded standard deviation is 0.87
The value of the median is 1

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Your Model Goes Here






Explain your model


\[
P_{\theta,\mathcal{Y}}(\mathbf{Y=y|X})=\frac{exp\{\theta^{\textsf{T}}g(y,X)\}}{\kappa(\theta,\mathcal{Y})}
\qquad(1)\]



Every time you refer to your equation use the tag (@referencetoequation) to refer to your equation like so (Equation 1).

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Line Highlighting

Highlight specific lines for emphasis
Incrementally highlight additional lines

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(subplot_kw={'projection': 'polar'})
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()

Learn more: Line Highlighting

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Easy Navigation
Quickly jump to other parts of your presentation
Toggle the slide menu with the menu button (bottom left of slide) to go to other slides and access presentation tools.
You can also press m to toggle the menu open and closed.

Learn more: Navigation

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
Chalkboard
Free form drawing and slide annotations
Use the chalkboard button at the bottom left of the slide to toggle the chalkboard.
Use the notes canvas button at the bottom left of the slide to toggle drawing on top of the current slide.
You can also press b to toggle the chalkboard or c to toggle the notes canvas.

Learn more: Chalkboard

title: Your Presentation Title Here
text:
References


Kermack, W. O., and A. G. McKendrick. 1939. “Contributions to the Mathematical Theory of Epidemics: V. Analysis of Experimental Epidemics of Mouse-Typhoid; a Bacterial Disease Conferring Incomplete Immunity.” Journal of Hygiene 39 (3): 271–88. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0022172400011918.


Rogers, Everett M. 1983. Diffusion of Innovations. 3. ed. New York, NY: Free Press.


Valente, Thomas W. 1996. “Social Network Thresholds in the Diffusion of Innovations.” Social Networks 18 (1): 69–89. https://doi.org/10.1016/0378-8733(95)00256-1.


Wasserman, Stanley, and Katherine Faust. 1994. Social Network Analysis: Methods and Applications. Structural Analysis in the Social Sciences. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. https://doi.org/10.1017/CBO9780511815478.
